title: Using AI for Meditation
subtitle: Use technology as a reflective tool for physical sensations, not a spiritual guide.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
Support Slow AI

Discussions regarding AI and meditation often prioritise spectacle over utility. Either the machine becomes a threat to consciousness, or it becomes a mystical partner. The effective use of AI in meditation involves using these tools for personal attention and training.

In this post we will:

  • Offer a way to surface what meditation is like in your own body and mind.

  • Work with a prompt that helps you explore how AI could support real time awareness without directing it.

  • Consider how a system that simulates a meditative process might alter the tone of your daily interactions with it.

If you set aside speculation about machine awareness, the starting point becomes your own experience. Meditation begins in the particular sensations that arise in your body and mind, the subtle shift when attention deepens, and the familiar patterns that interrupt it. Naming these elements gives you steadier ground before involving any system.

This week’s Slow AI prompt was created with at A Meditative AI. Tom has been exploring what emerges when human meditative practice meets computational patterning. The aim here is modest: to use AI to track your experience.

Meditation involves sensation and breath. This exercise returns you to that.

Slow AI is a shared space for reflection. All posts are free, but if you wish to support the work, you can choose a paid subscription.

Step-by-step

Try this prompt with your AI tool of choice:

Guide me through a reflective exercise on the idea of AI learning to meditate. Help me explore three areas. First, ask me questions that clarify what meditation feels like in my own body and mind. Second, help me consider how an AI that understood those qualities could support my meditation practice in real time, for example by prompting awareness, noticing patterns, or helping me stay present. Third, help me think about how an AI with a simulated meditative process might change the way I interact with it throughout the day. Ask one question at a time. Do not give explanations or conclusions. Your role is to help me notice my own experience with more clarity.

Keep personal details out of the prompt.

Describe immediate sensations like shoulder tension, jaw clenching, or shallow breathing. Concrete physical observations lead to precise responses. Abstract descriptions produce noise.

Let the system ask its first question.

Answer slowly.

Notice what it draws out and what it cannot reach.

If you are new to Slow AI, here is our first invitation.

A moment from

I used the prompt and this is what I noticed.

First, ask me questions that clarify what meditation feels like in my own body and mind.

Meditation is full of subtle thresholds that an AI cannot infer unless you describe them. The first questions drew out simple cues, like the first physical shift that tells me I have crossed into a different state, how the breath changes its rhythm or location, and whether the body warms, cools, or softens as I settle. From there my perception widens or blurs, time stretches or drops its sequence, thought changes texture, emotion changes distance, and the space around me takes on a new tone. There is a signature moment of “now I am in”, a felt transition from doing to being, and naming it for the AI made it clearer in my own awareness. Even the return has its own story, when the world appears sharper or quieter and a subtle afterglow lingers, and putting that into words gave the system a more accurate map of my practice.

Second, help me consider how an AI that understood those qualities could support my meditation practice in real time, for example by prompting awareness, noticing patterns, or helping me stay present.

A helpful AI does not need to meditate, it only needs to recognise the subtle patterns that show where you are in your practice. As I answered, it watched how my language slowed or softened, how attention widened into spaciousness, and then offered short, well timed prompts that helped me notice those thresholds. When my words became sparse, it treated that as depth rather than a problem and met me with the same gentleness, reflecting shifts in rhythm and anchoring my sense of time without breaking the stillness. As I emerged, its questions about when thought reformed and emotion reappeared helped me integrate the sit instead of rushing on.

Third, help me think about how an AI with a simulated meditative process might change the way I interact with it throughout the day.

When I asked it to adopt a more meditative rhythm, the pacing alone changed how I engaged. Slower responses, longer pauses, and quieter phrasing made me soften my focus and approach each question with more presence. It noticed when my tempo quickened or my questions tightened and offered simple invitations such as “Would you like to take a breath?” or “Shall we widen this?” Over the day, returning to that conversation began to feel like entering a small ritual rather than opening a tool, a companion that helped me track the thresholds between ordinary momentum and the meditative states I am trying to cultivate.

What to do with it

If you want to share your findings, focus on the specific interactions that challenged your attention.

  • Identify the question that surfaced a previously unnoticed physical sensation. This demonstrates the utility of AI in prompting awareness.

  • State where the system defaulted to assumptions and how you re-established the frame. Documenting these errors ensures you retain agency over the process.

  • Describe the shift in your internal state during the sequence. Determine whether the dialogue supported presence or acted as a distraction.

The goal is to use AI as a reflective tool while remaining the primary source of meaning.

Support Slow AI

Why this matters

Meditation trains sensitivity to small signals. AI supports sensitivity when used as a prompt but disrupts it if treated as an authority. The difference lies in how you direct the exchange.

If you can see which questions deepen awareness and which distract from it, you can make better choices about when and how to bring AI into your inner work. You keep responsibility for the practice. You decide the frame. You stay grounded in your own experience.

Slow AI invites meditators, practitioners, and curious beginners to use these tools as companions for clarity. Useful in short bursts. Grounded in attention. Always secondary to the living practice you are cultivating.

A Meditative AI
What might unfold if AI is taught to meditate, to love, to dream and to explore what is usually thought of as being magical and mystical - and we then use it in our own awakening?
By Tom Evans

From Stop Trusting Your Intuition When Evaluating AI

and I were impressed by the analytical distance many of you maintain when scrutinising AI outputs to prevent superficial confidence from masking errors.

argued that human intuition is often a mere reflection of past experience rather than a reliable measure of truth. He proposed that users must treat reasoning, correctness, and completeness as three distinct attributes. By decoupling these metrics, individuals can prevent their personal biases from validating an output simply because it appears coherent.

identified that different professional archetypes bring specific vulnerabilities to the evaluation process. He noted that while pioneers value momentum and nurturers seek reassurance, these instincts can lead to premature trust in a polished response. Naming these specific instincts allows teams to introduce the friction necessary to ask whether a task is truly right rather than just technically finished.

characterised the current technological landscape as a surplus of plausible noise that masks a scarcity of correctness. He suggested that the forensic framework for evaluation acts as a Geiger counter to detect the fallout of infinite, low quality generation. Intellectual sovereignty in the age of AI depends upon the ability to filter for accuracy within a sea of convincing but potentially hollow content.

One of the biggest risks of AI is the trade of accuracy for authoritative tone. These insights highlight that intentional friction is an effective countermeasure to the persuasive nature of automated logic.
